clinical_note: Matthew Perry is a 17-year-old male with history notable for ataxia with unsteady, wide-based gait and impaired coordination, described as difficulty with tandem walking and occasional overshooting on finger-to-nose testing, with functional impact including slower performance in sports and increased need to hold railings on stairs. He also carries a history of acidosis with recurrent low serum bicarbonate on prior chemistry panels, consistent with a metabolic acidosis pattern; recent representative labs show CO₂ (bicarbonate) 16–18 mmol/L on multiple checks with an anion gap around 10–12, and venous blood gas pH 7.30–7.33, indicating a persistent rather than isolated abnormality. Episodes are reported to be more noticeable during intercurrent illness with worsened fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance, but baseline low bicarbonate has also been documented. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with long-standing problems with balance and coordination described as “ataxia,” and a paternal cousin with recurrent metabolic acidosis requiring hospital evaluation in childhood; no parental consanguinity is reported.

Timothy Parker is a 13-year-old male with history notable for a disorder of phenylalanine metabolism and recurrent episodes of seizure activity. Records describe persistent hyperphenylalaninemia on monitoring, with plasma phenylalanine typically in the 900–1200 µmol/L range on several checks over the past year (most recently 1050 µmol/L), with comparatively normal tyrosine around 55–75 µmol/L, consistent with ongoing elevation rather than a single episodic spike. Clinically, he has had intermittent seizure-like events characterized by sudden loss of awareness with generalized stiffening and rhythmic shaking, lasting approximately 1–2 minutes, followed by post-event sleepiness and confusion for 20–30 minutes; episodes have occurred a few times per year and have resulted in missed school days after events. Family history is significant for a paternal uncle with a childhood-onset seizure disorder and a maternal cousin reported to have elevated phenylalanine on newborn screening requiring ongoing dietary management.

Richard Wood is a 9-year-old male with a history notable for atrial septal defect and congenital polycystic kidney disease. Neurodevelopmentally, he carries severe intellectual disability with significant limitations in adaptive functioning; he requires close supervision for daily activities and has marked impairment in communication and learning. He also has a documented multiple congenital anomaly syndrome, and exam is described as dysmorphic with a long, narrow face and low-set ears. Medical history is thus characterized by co-occurring congenital cardiac and renal malformations alongside severe cognitive impairment. Family history is not available in the provided record. Prior genetic evaluation included chromosomal microarray testing performed on 2025-11-16, which was reported as negative.

Larry Howard is a 3-year-old male with history notable for ataxia characterized by an unsteady, wide-based gait and poor coordination, with frequent stumbling and difficulty with balance during running and stair climbing. Parents report these coordination problems are persistent rather than episodic and interfere with age-appropriate play. Laboratory history is notable for other specified abnormal findings of blood chemistry; available records show persistently elevated serum lactate in the 3.0–3.8 mmol/L range (ref 0.5–2.2) on repeat measurements over several months, with intermittent mild elevation of plasma ammonia to 70–85 µmol/L (ref <50). These biochemical findings have been documented on more than one occasion rather than as a single isolated result. Family history is significant for consanguinity, as the parents are first cousins. A paternal uncle is reported to have longstanding gait unsteadiness and poor coordination since childhood, and a maternal cousin has a history of recurrent abnormal blood chemistry testing described by the family as “high lactate,” without additional documented details.

Christina Henderson is a 19-year-old female with history notable for congenital pulmonary valve atresia, requiring ongoing cardiology follow-up for a complex right-sided outflow tract defect. She also carries a diagnosis of congenital hepatic fibropolycystic disease with renal involvement, described clinically as congenital hepatic fibrosis with associated cystic kidney disease; imaging history has included enlarged, echogenic kidneys with multiple cysts and a fibrotic-appearing liver, with intermittent abdominal fullness but no acute decompensation documented today. Developmental history is significant for global developmental delay, with persistent delays in learning and adaptive skills that have impacted school performance and independence with age-appropriate tasks. A syndromic pattern is documented consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance; on exam she has mild facial dysmorphism with a broad nasal bridge and low-set ears. Prior genetic testing is on record: chromosomal microarray performed 2025-06-10 was negative.

Brenda Phillips is a 6-year-old female with a history notable for an atrial septal defect and congenital cystic kidney disease consistent with medullary sponge kidney. Developmental history includes specific developmental disorder of motor function, with persistent difficulty in age-expected coordination and fine/gross motor tasks that affects daily activities and school participation. She also carries a diagnosis of Fanconi syndrome, with a syndromic presentation that includes dysmorphic features; on exam she has mild facial asymmetry and low-set ears. The congenital heart defect has been followed clinically, with symptoms and functional limitations described in the context of the known septal defect rather than as a separate cardiopulmonary diagnosis. Renal history is characterized by the congenital cystic changes typical of medullary sponge kidney, with ongoing monitoring for related renal manifestations as part of her established condition. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-12-08, which was reported as negative.

Jeffrey Jackson is a 17-year-old male with history notable for a disorder of phenylalanine metabolism and persistent incoordination/ataxia affecting gait and fine motor control. Family reports long-standing clumsiness with frequent stumbling and difficulty with rapid alternating movements; symptoms are present daily and have interfered with sports participation and handwriting speed, without describing a specific focal weakness pattern. Metabolic monitoring has shown chronically elevated plasma phenylalanine levels with dietary sensitivity, with representative recent values of phenylalanine 980 µmol/L (ref 30–120) and an elevated phenylalanine:tyrosine ratio of 14:1 (tyrosine 70 µmol/L), described as persistently high rather than episodic. No additional metabolic analytes are reported as abnormal. Family history is significant for an older sister with the same phenylalanine metabolism disorder requiring ongoing dietary management, and a maternal uncle reported to have lifelong coordination difficulties consistent with ataxia; the parents deny consanguinity.

Pamela Morgan is a 12-year-old female with a history notable for congenital brain malformation consistent with holoprosencephaly, accompanied by dysmorphic features including microtia of the external ear and subtle midline facial differences. She has a documented congenital esophageal atresia, with early feeding and swallowing difficulties related to the structural interruption of the esophagus; current history continues to reference the congenital condition when reviewing growth and nutrition. Neurodevelopmental history is significant for a specific developmental disorder of motor function, with longstanding impairment in coordination and fine-motor control that affects daily tasks such as handwriting, dressing skills, and age-expected gross motor activities. The overall phenotype has been described as a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance, and clinical documentation emphasizes the co-occurrence of craniofacial and central nervous system findings rather than a single isolated anomaly. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-11-15, reported as negative.

Daniel Thomas is a 4-year-old male with a complex congenital and neurodevelopmental history. Since infancy he has had esophageal atresia with tracheo-esophageal fistula, requiring early surgical management and ongoing feeding and swallowing vulnerability with intermittent coughing/choking during meals per caregiver report. Congenital renal involvement includes medullary cystic kidney disease with bilateral medullary cysts noted on renal ultrasound; family reports periodic monitoring for hydration status and urine output, without specific acute decompensations described today. Musculoskeletal history is notable for other congenital deformity of the feet, with persistent foot malalignment affecting gait and shoe fit. Neurodevelopmental course is consistent with moderate intellectual disability, with delays in adaptive skills and need for close supervision for safety and daily routines. He is described as dysmorphic, with a short philtrum and low-set ears on exam, in the setting of a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance. Prior genetic testing included a gene panel on 2025-10-17 that was reported as negative.

Secondary medical issues/histories include a recent concussion without loss of consciousness, a superficial burn of an unspecified degree involving the head/face/neck region, and an open scalp wound, all documented as acute injuries without additional sequelae described in today’s record.

Justin Morris is a 15-year-old male with history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism and recurrent seizure-like episodes. Events have been described as sudden spells of unresponsiveness with generalized stiffening and rhythmic jerking lasting 1–2 minutes, followed by post-event sleepiness and confusion for up to an hour; frequency has been intermittent with clusters during intercurrent illness and after missed meals, impacting school attendance and sports participation. Metabolic evaluation has shown persistently elevated plasma lactate (3.8–4.6 mmol/L; reference 0.5–2.2) with an increased lactate-to-pyruvate ratio (28–32), and episodic mild metabolic acidosis during febrile illnesses (bicarbonate 17–19 mmol/L). Family history is significant for parental consanguinity, as the parents are first cousins. A maternal uncle reportedly had childhood-onset seizures, and a paternal cousin has a diagnosed mitochondrial metabolic disorder with exercise intolerance. No prior genetic test results were available for review in the record provided.

Secondary medical issues include a recent right ankle sprain with pain and swelling after an inversion injury, and a concussion without loss of consciousness following a head impact, with transient headache and dizziness that resolved over several days.

Deborah Moore is a 4-year-old female seen after multiple acute injuries and an ingestion event. History is notable for an open wound of the scalp with active bleeding at the time of presentation, described as a laceration without mention of intracranial involvement; the family reports it occurred suddenly and required prompt wound care due to persistent oozing and tenderness at the site. She also has an acute burn involving the head/face/neck region, described as a burn of unspecified degree, with localized pain and erythema; the affected area is sensitive to touch and has interfered with normal sleep and routine activities. In addition, there is concern for accidental penicillin exposure with features consistent with poisoning by penicillins, described as an unintentional ingestion; caregivers report the event was abrupt and prompted urgent evaluation for potential medication toxicity. Family history is notable for consanguinity, with the parents reported to be first cousins. No prior diagnostic testing results were provided in the available record for today’s visit.

Helen Edwards is a 8-year-old female seen following an acute head injury consistent with concussion without loss of consciousness. History describes immediate headache and light sensitivity after the event, with transient dizziness and nausea but no reported blackout; she has had difficulty concentrating and increased fatigue that have interfered with schoolwork since the injury. She also sustained an unspecified burn of the head and face; exam documentation notes erythema and superficial blistering involving facial skin without a clearly recorded depth, with localized pain and tenderness. In addition, there is an episode of accidental exposure to a systemic antibiotic in the penicillin class, described as an unintentional ingestion/medication error; following the exposure she developed acute gastrointestinal upset with vomiting and abdominal discomfort, without details suggesting intent of self-harm. No family history or consanguinity information was provided. No prior genetic or diagnostic testing results were available in the record for review.

Elizabeth Mitchell is a 7-year-old female with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency, with lactose exposure provoking reproducible gastrointestinal intolerance since infancy. Caregivers report symptoms after dairy intake consistent with dietary sensitivity; recent supporting labs include a low lactase activity on intestinal enzyme assay (0.4 U/g tissue, ref >10) and a lactose hydrogen breath test showing a rise of 38 ppm above baseline at 90 minutes, with symptoms recurring episodically when lactose is not avoided. Neurologic history is significant for other generalized epilepsy without intractable epilepsy, described as recurrent generalized seizures occurring approximately 1–2 times per month over the past year, with postictal fatigue and transient confusion affecting school participation the following day; no history of status epilepticus is noted. Family history is notable for a maternal uncle with generalized epilepsy beginning in adolescence and a paternal cousin with childhood-onset seizures; parents deny consanguinity.

Maria Lopez is a 10-year-old female with history notable for lactose intolerance, described as reproducible abdominal cramping, bloating, and loose stools after milk, ice cream, or other lactose-containing foods, with improvement when lactose is avoided or lactase enzyme is used. Neurologic history is notable for epilepsy characterized by recurrent seizures that have continued despite prior anti-seizure medication trials, with events reported as intermittent episodes of impaired awareness with generalized convulsive activity and postictal fatigue, occurring several times per month and impacting school attendance and daytime functioning. Metabolic evaluation has included serial serum lactase-related carbohydrate tolerance testing consistent with lactose intolerance, with hydrogen breath testing showing a rise in breath hydrogen to 45 ppm above baseline within 90 minutes after lactose challenge, and symptoms reproduced during testing; this pattern has been persistent over time rather than episodic. Family history is significant for epilepsy in a maternal uncle with ongoing seizures into adulthood. The parents are first cousins, and there is also a paternal cousin reported to have childhood-onset seizures requiring long-term medication.

Barbara Perez is a 9-year-old female with a history notable for agenesis of the corpus callosum and severe intellectual disability, with global functional limitations requiring close supervision for daily activities and learning. Craniofacial and musculoskeletal findings include plagiocephaly with persistent asymmetric head shape noted since early childhood, and congenital facial malformation characterized by blepharophimosis with narrowed palpebral fissures affecting the appearance of the eyelids. Dysmorphic features on exam are described by a small-appearing palpebral opening consistent with blepharophimosis and visible cranial asymmetry consistent with plagiocephaly. The overall presentation is consistent with a multiple congenital anomalies pattern in which the above structural findings and neurodevelopmental impairment co-occur. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-09-05, which was negative.

Sarah Martin is a 9-year-old female with history notable for congenital absence of the external ear, with persistent auricular asymmetry on exam and associated dysmorphic facial features including a small mandible and downslanting palpebral fissures. She has a documented congenital interruption of the esophagus, with early feeding difficulty and ongoing need for careful pacing of solids and liquids; caregivers report intermittent coughing with rapid feeds but no description of a new acute obstruction. Neurodevelopmental history includes a congenital malformation of the brain described in prior records, and she carries a developmental speech and language disorder with delayed expressive language and reduced intelligibility that affects classroom participation and social interactions, requiring frequent repetition and support for age-appropriate communication. Overall phenotype is consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome involving multiple congenital anomalies, with multisystem involvement across craniofacial/auricular, foregut, and central nervous system domains. Prior testing includes a gene panel performed on 2025-08-27 that was negative.

Maria Bailey is an 8-year-old female with history notable for lactose intolerance and epilepsy characterized by other generalized seizures, not intractable, without status epilepticus. Caregivers describe recurrent episodes of generalized seizure activity with return to baseline between events and no history of prolonged convulsions requiring emergent treatment for status. She has dietary sensitivity to lactose with reproducible gastrointestinal symptoms after dairy exposure; symptoms improve with lactose avoidance and use of lactose-free alternatives. Metabolic evaluation has shown episodic carbohydrate malabsorption consistent with lactase deficiency, including a hydrogen breath test demonstrating a rise to 42 ppm above baseline after lactose load, with associated cramping and loose stools, and normal tolerance of non-lactose carbohydrates. Family history is significant for seizures in a maternal uncle with generalized epilepsy beginning in adolescence and a paternal cousin with recurrent generalized seizures; there is no reported consanguinity. Overall functioning is impacted by the need for strict dietary modification to prevent post-dairy gastrointestinal symptoms and by intermittent seizure events requiring supervision and activity precautions.

Jacob Hernandez is a 3-year-old male with history notable for congenital hepatic fibrosis with associated polycystic kidney disease, and craniofacial features consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome characterized by craniosynostosis. Parents report that since infancy he has had a persistently protuberant-appearing left eye consistent with congenital exophthalmos, without reported acute eye pain. Developmentally, he demonstrates a speech and language delay: expressive language remains limited for age with reduced intelligibility and difficulty combining words into longer phrases, impacting communication at home and in early learning settings. Dysmorphic features on exam are notable for an abnormal head shape suggestive of premature suture fusion and midface hypoplasia. No additional neurobehavioral diagnoses are documented beyond the language disorder. Prior testing includes a gene panel performed on 2026-01-11, which was negative.

Victoria Jones is an 8-year-old female with history notable for developmental delay with moderate intellectual disability, requiring ongoing support for learning and adaptive skills. She has craniofacial and musculoskeletal findings consistent with a congenital multiple-anomaly pattern, including a congenital facial asymmetry with hemifacial underdevelopment and associated jaw/facial contour imbalance, along with a congenital chest wall configuration described as pectus carinatum. Cardiac history includes a known atrial septal defect consistent with an ostium secundum-type defect, followed clinically as a structural congenital heart finding. Dysmorphic features on exam are characterized by clear facial asymmetry and a prominent anterior chest wall contour. Prior genetic evaluation included a single-gene test performed on 2025-12-01, which was reported as negative.

Donald Wright is an 11-year-old male with a history notable for a congenital brain malformation consistent with holoprosencephaly, accompanied by dysmorphic craniofacial features including a flattened midface and closely spaced eyes. He also carries a diagnosis of Russell-Silver syndrome and has significant global functional impairment consistent with severe intellectual disability, with longstanding limitations in learning and adaptive skills requiring substantial assistance for daily activities and supervision. His medical course has been characterized by multiple congenital anomalies in the setting of these established diagnoses, without expanding beyond the specific syndromic labels documented. Prior genetic evaluation included chromosomal microarray testing (CMA) performed on 2025-09-09, which was reported as negative.

Sarah Ross is a 5-year-old female with history notable for a disorder of phenylalanine metabolism and neonatal hypotonia. Records describe persistently elevated plasma phenylalanine on metabolic monitoring, with representative values around 680–820 µmol/L on several checks, while tyrosine has remained within reference range; elevations are described as chronic rather than episodic and have been tracked longitudinally. Early history includes decreased neonatal tone with “floppy” appearance and reduced spontaneous movement noted in the newborn period; caregivers reported weak antigravity limb activity and poor head control early on, with gradual improvement over time. There is a relevant family history of similar phenylalanine metabolism disorder in an older sibling and a paternal cousin, both described as requiring ongoing biochemical monitoring. The parents are first cousins, which is documented in the family pedigree. No additional syndromic features are described beyond the above, and the clinical narrative remains focused on the metabolic phenotype and the early hypotonia noted in infancy.

Brandon Parker is a 7-year-old male with history notable for a disorder of aromatic amino-acid metabolism and abnormal coordination. Caregivers describe longstanding clumsiness with an unsteady gait, frequent tripping, and difficulty with balance during running and stairs; fine-motor tasks such as handwriting and utensil use are slower than peers and fatigue with repetitive coordination is reported. Metabolic monitoring has shown persistently elevated plasma phenylalanine, with recent values around 920 µmol/L (reference 30–120) and prior levels commonly in the 650–1,100 µmol/L range, with episodic worsening during intercurrent illness; tyrosine has been low-normal at approximately 45 µmol/L (reference 35–110). No additional neurologic syndrome is documented beyond the observed ataxic features. Family history is significant for an older brother with a similar aromatic amino-acid metabolism disorder requiring ongoing biochemical surveillance, and the parents report they are first cousins.

Jason Lopez is a 7-year-old male with a history notable for multiple congenital anomalies and neurodevelopmental impairment. He has congenital malformations of the feet, described by the family as longstanding structural foot differences present since birth that have affected shoe fit and gait. He also carries a diagnosis of congenital polycystic kidney disease, with known renal cystic involvement identified in childhood and followed clinically. Neonatal history includes esophageal atresia, repaired early in life, with ongoing need for careful feeding habits per caregiver report. Developmentally, he meets criteria for moderate intellectual disability with persistent limitations in learning and adaptive functioning, requiring substantial support in school and daily routines. A congenital malformation syndrome is documented, and exam is notable for dysmorphic features including low-set ears and a flattened nasal bridge. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-09-12, which was negative. Family history was not provided in the available record.

Gary Smith is a 5-year-old male with a history notable for a congenital malformation syndrome associated with multiple congenital anomalies and developmental differences. Congenital ocular involvement includes a specified eyelid malformation present since infancy, described by the family as an abnormal eyelid contour that intermittently affects the palpebral opening and contributes to noticeable facial asymmetry. Examination is also notable for mild dysmorphic features with a broad nasal bridge and low-set ears. Cardiac history includes a secundum atrial septal defect identified in early childhood, followed clinically without reported cyanotic episodes, and with activity tolerance described as similar to peers for routine play. Neurodevelopmentally, he has a diagnosis of specific developmental disorder of motor function; caregivers report persistent fine and gross motor coordination difficulties, including trouble with handwriting-like tasks, utensil use, and frequent tripping with running, impacting participation in age-appropriate sports and requiring extra time for self-care tasks. Prior genetic testing included single-gene analysis performed on 2025-10-24, reported as negative.

David Bailey is a 13-year-old male with a history notable for congenital craniofacial findings and neurodevelopmental differences. Since birth he has had macrocephaly, with head size persistently above age expectations, and dysmorphic features including a cleft palate and a congenital eyelid malformation consistent with blepharoptosis. He also has a congenital malformation of the ear, described historically as a small accessory auricle/tag. Neuroimaging and clinical documentation indicate holoprosencephaly, and developmental history is notable for a specific developmental disorder of motor function, with ongoing difficulty in coordination and motor planning that affects fine motor tasks and age-appropriate gross motor activities. The overall phenotype is consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome involving structures of the face and brain. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-12-14, which was reported as negative.

Jeffrey Jackson is a 13-year-old male. History is notable for lactose intolerance with reproducible gastrointestinal symptoms after ingestion of milk, ice cream, and other lactose-containing foods, including crampy abdominal pain, bloating, and loose stools; symptoms improve with lactose avoidance and use of lactase enzyme tablets, and there is no report of similar reactions to non-dairy foods. Neurologic history includes recurrent seizure episodes described as sudden behavioral arrest with unresponsiveness and occasional generalized stiffening and rhythmic jerking, lasting 1–2 minutes with post-event confusion and fatigue; events have occurred intermittently over the past year, sometimes triggered by sleep deprivation, and have led to missed school days and restrictions from sports due to safety concerns. Family history is significant for seizures in a maternal uncle (adult-onset, treated with antiseizure medication) and lactose intolerance in the father. The parents are first cousins. Metabolic features are limited to lactose sensitivity; no other specific metabolic disorder is documented in the available history.

Sharon Brown is an 8-year-old female with a history notable for congenital cardiac malformations including pulmonary valve atresia and a secundum atrial septal defect. Developmental history is significant for moderate intellectual disability with global learning limitations and the need for substantial support for school-based academics and adaptive skills. She also carries a diagnosis of a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance; on exam she has dysmorphic facial features with a broad nasal bridge and low-set ears. There is no suggestion here of an acquired cause for her neurodevelopmental profile; her course is described as longstanding rather than acute. Prior genetic evaluation is documented: single-gene testing performed on 2025-10-25 was negative.

Robert Scott is a 10-year-old male with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency with dietary sensitivity since infancy. Caregivers report that exposure to lactose-containing foods reliably triggers gastrointestinal intolerance with watery stools, abdominal cramping, and bloating; symptoms improve with strict lactose avoidance and recur within hours of accidental ingestion. He has had intermittent nutritional monitoring, and recent labs obtained during symptomatic periods showed a positive stool reducing substances test and low stool pH (5.0), with otherwise stable basic metabolic parameters; the pattern has been persistent rather than episodic. Neurologic history is notable for ataxia manifested as unsteady, wide-based gait and poor coordination, with difficulty running and frequent tripping compared with peers; fine motor tasks such as handwriting and utensil use are described as clumsy, with fluctuating severity but ongoing functional impact at school and during sports. Family history is significant for similar lactose intolerance in the father and a paternal aunt. The parents are first cousins, and there is also a maternal cousin reported to have chronic gait imbalance consistent with ataxia.

Maria Nelson is a 9-year-old female with a history notable for congenital anomalies and developmental motor delay. She has been followed for blepharophimosis with a narrowed palpebral fissure and associated eyelid narrowing noted since infancy. She also has a congenital esophageal atresia, with early feeding difficulties and need for surgical repair in infancy per outside records, and she continues to have intermittent dysphagia with certain textures. Neurodevelopmental history includes abnormalities of the corpus callosum identified on prior neuroimaging, with associated functional impact in coordination and motor planning. She carries a diagnosis of specific developmental disorder of motor function, described by caregivers as persistent fine and gross motor delays affecting handwriting, dressing tasks, and participation in age-appropriate sports despite supportive therapies. Dysmorphic features documented on exam include facial asymmetry and mild micrognathia. Her presentation has been considered within the scope of a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance. Prior genetic testing includes chromosomal microarray performed on 2025-12-03, reported as negative.

Anthony Davis is a 3-year-old male with history notable for episodic seizures of unclear type, described by caregivers as sudden stiffening with rhythmic jerking lasting 1–2 minutes and followed by several hours of sleepiness; events have occurred intermittently since infancy and have led to urgent evaluations. He also carries a history of acidosis, with prior laboratory documentation of low serum bicarbonate (typically 14–16 mmol/L) and an elevated anion gap (about 18–22), noted on more than one occasion rather than as a single isolated finding. Caregivers report these acidotic episodes are most apparent during intercurrent illnesses with decreased oral intake, when he becomes more fatigued and tachypneic, prompting repeat blood testing. Family history is significant for consanguinity, as the parents are first cousins. A paternal uncle is reported to have had recurrent seizures beginning in childhood, and a maternal cousin has a history of episodic “blood acid” problems requiring hospital care, without further diagnostic details available in the record.

Paul Roberts is an 11-year-old male with history notable for hyperphenylalaninemia and epilepsy characterized as other generalized epilepsy with intractable seizures, without status epilepticus. Metabolic monitoring has shown persistently elevated plasma phenylalanine levels, most recently 780 µmol/L (reference 30–120) with tyrosine at the low end of normal at 35 µmol/L (reference 30–120), with prior values typically ranging 600–900 µmol/L during periods of dietary liberalization. Caregivers describe sensitivity of levels to protein intake, with episodic rises noted after higher-protein meals. Neurologically, he has recurrent generalized seizures that remain difficult to control, occurring several times per month with postictal sleepiness and missed school days; there has been no history of convulsive status epilepticus. Family history is significant for an older maternal uncle with a childhood-onset seizure disorder and a paternal cousin reported to have elevated phenylalanine detected on newborn screening; no parental consanguinity is reported.

Nicholas Anderson is an 11-year-old male with a history notable for congenital cardiac findings including an atrial septal defect and pulmonary valve atresia, with associated congenital malformation of the tricuspid valve. He also carries a diagnosis of Apert syndrome, and on exam has dysmorphic craniofacial features consistent with this condition, including midface hypoplasia and a flattened nasal bridge. Ocular history includes congenital blepharophimosis, described as narrowed palpebral fissures with reduced eyelid opening. Developmentally, there is an established speech and language disorder, with persistent delays in expressive and/or receptive language impacting age-expected communication in school and at home. His overall medical course includes multiple congenital anomalies consistent with the above syndromic diagnosis, without implying a single unifying mechanism beyond the documented conditions. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-09-06, which was negative.

Sarah Reed is a 9-year-old female with a history notable for atrial septal defect and multiple congenital anomalies. Craniofacial findings include a preauricular tag, and she has a dysmorphic appearance with mild facial asymmetry and low-set ears. She also has a congenital foot deformity described as other specified congenital deformities of the feet, contributing to gait differences and difficulty with prolonged walking. Neurodevelopmentally, she carries a diagnosis of moderate intellectual disability with global learning limitations, requiring substantial support at school and in daily adaptive skills; caregivers describe persistent challenges with age-appropriate academic progress and problem-solving. The overall pattern is consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance. Family history is not reported as contributory in the available record. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2026-01-04, which was negative.

Donna Price is a 5-year-old female with history notable for a mitochondrial metabolism disorder and epilepsy characterized by generalized seizures without status epilepticus. Seizure burden has been variable, with episodes described as sudden loss of awareness with generalized stiffening and rhythmic jerking lasting 1–2 minutes, followed by postictal sleepiness and confusion; events have occurred both during wakefulness and sleep and have led to missed preschool activities due to fatigue after episodes. Metabolic monitoring has shown a persistent pattern of lactic acid elevation, with venous lactate typically 3.5–4.8 mmol/L (reference 0.5–2.2) on multiple draws, sometimes higher during intercurrent illness, along with intermittent mild metabolic acidosis (bicarbonate 18–20 mmol/L). Family history is significant for consanguinity, with the parents reported to be first cousins. There is also a reported history of seizures in a maternal uncle beginning in childhood, without documented status epilepticus, and a paternal cousin with a known mitochondrial metabolism disorder diagnosed in early childhood.

Thomas Gonzalez is a 10-year-old male with a history notable for infantile polycystic kidney disease, with ongoing renal involvement requiring longitudinal monitoring. He also has a documented congenital esophageal atresia, repaired in infancy per family report, with persistent feeding-related symptoms including intermittent dysphagia and slow eating, particularly with textured solids. Craniofacial and auricular findings include anotia, with external ear absence affecting hearing-related function and communication access. Neurodevelopmental history includes developmental delay with prominent speech and language delay; caregivers describe limited expressive vocabulary for age and reduced intelligibility, impacting school participation and peer interactions. Dysmorphic features are noted on exam, including low-set ears and mild facial asymmetry, in the context of a congenital malformation syndrome. Family history is noncontributory as provided. Prior genetic testing included single-gene analysis performed on 2025-11-07, reported as negative.

Deborah Evans is a 7-year-old female with history notable for multiple congenital anomalies and developmental concerns. She has congenital absence of the external ear, described by the family as being present since birth and associated with visible auricular malformation on the affected side. She also has a history of esophageal atresia diagnosed in infancy, requiring early surgical management, with ongoing feeding-related vulnerability characterized by slow eating and occasional coughing with thin liquids. Cardiac history includes pulmonary valve atresia, followed since infancy with congenital heart disease surveillance and activity limitation during intercurrent illness. Developmentally, she demonstrates a specific motor delay with persistent fine and gross motor coordination difficulties; caregivers describe clumsiness, delayed acquisition of complex motor tasks, and difficulty with handwriting and dressing fasteners compared with peers, impacting school participation. Dysmorphic features include a notably malformed external ear and facial asymmetry on exam. Overall phenotype has been labeled as a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance. Prior genetic testing included chromosomal microarray performed on 2025-10-01, which was negative.

Timothy Walker is a 3-year-old male with history notable for epilepsy characterized by generalized seizures that have not been fully controlled. Events are described as sudden loss of awareness with generalized stiffening and rhythmic jerking, occurring about 1–2 times per month despite adherence to prescribed antiseizure therapy, with postictal sleepiness lasting 1–2 hours and intermittent disruption of daycare attendance. He also carries a history of metabolic acidosis with documented low serum bicarbonate and elevated anion gap on multiple occasions; representative recent labs include CO₂ 16 mmol/L (ref 22–29) with anion gap 18, with similar values noted on repeat testing during intercurrent illness and occasionally when well, suggesting a persistent tendency with episodic worsening. During more pronounced episodes, caregivers report tachypnea and decreased oral intake, prompting urgent evaluation. Family history is significant for seizures in a maternal uncle beginning in childhood and a paternal cousin with recurrent “convulsions,” with no known consanguinity reported between the parents.

Kevin Parker is a 8-year-old male with history notable for moderate intellectual disability with global developmental delay, requiring ongoing support for learning and adaptive skills. He has a congenital cardiac septal defect described as an atrial septal defect, with prior clinical follow-up for a structural heart finding rather than an acquired cardiac condition. Dysmorphic features are present in the setting of a congenital malformation syndrome, including facial asymmetry consistent with plagiocephaly and a persistently asymmetric head shape noted since infancy. The overall presentation is framed as a specific congenital malformation syndrome with associated intellectual disability and craniofacial differences, without extending beyond the documented phenotype. A prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-08-27, which was reported as negative.

Nicholas Cook is a 9-year-old male with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency with lifelong intolerance to lactose-containing foods. Caregivers describe predictable gastrointestinal symptoms after dairy exposure, including crampy abdominal pain and loose stools that improve with strict avoidance and use of lactose-free alternatives; symptoms recur promptly with accidental ingestion, suggesting ongoing dietary sensitivity rather than a transient issue. Neurologic history is notable for episodes of seizures without a specified type; events have been intermittent, with sudden onset of altered responsiveness and generalized shaking reported by family, followed by post-event sleepiness, and these episodes have interfered with school attendance on days they occur. Metabolic evaluation has shown low lactase activity consistent with congenital lactase deficiency, and nutritional monitoring has included periodic stool testing demonstrating persistently acidic stool (pH ~5.0) with positive reducing substances during symptomatic periods after lactose exposure. Family history is significant for similar dairy intolerance in the father and recurrent seizure episodes in a paternal uncle. The parents are first cousins.

Scott Evans is a 10-year-old male with a history notable for a congenital syndrome characterized by craniofacial and limb involvement, with dysmorphic features including downslanting palpebral fissures and mild fifth-finger clinodactyly. Ocular history includes congenital blepharoptosis with functional impact on vision, described as a persistent drooping of the upper eyelids since infancy. Cardiac history includes a secundum atrial septal defect identified in childhood, followed clinically without additional detail available in this record. Neurodevelopmental history is significant for a specific developmental disorder of motor function, with longstanding fine- and gross-motor coordination difficulties that affect handwriting, dressing skills, and participation in age-appropriate sports, without characterization here as a broader cognitive disorder. He has multiple congenital anomalies consistent with the above syndrome and associated findings. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-10-18, reported as negative.

Monica Rodriguez is a 10-year-old female with history notable for congenital hypotonia, described since infancy as low axial tone with “floppiness,” delayed head control, and persistent difficulty with prolonged sitting posture and stair climbing compared with peers; symptoms have been stable without a clear episodic pattern and continue to affect endurance for age-appropriate activities. She also carries a diagnosis of congenital lactase deficiency with reproducible gastrointestinal intolerance to lactose-containing foods. Caregivers report that even small amounts of milk or ice cream trigger watery diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain within a few hours, with improvement when lactose is strictly avoided. Prior metabolic evaluation has documented low small-bowel lactase activity (0.5 U/g; reference ≥10 U/g) and repeated low lactose tolerance testing with minimal rise in serum glucose after lactose load (increase 8 mg/dL), consistent with a persistent enzymatic deficiency rather than intermittent intolerance. Family history is significant for an older brother with similar lifelong lactose-triggered diarrhea requiring strict dietary avoidance, and a maternal aunt reported to have had low muscle tone in infancy requiring physical therapy. Parents deny consanguinity.

Christine Nelson is a 13-year-old female with a history notable for congenital malformations including other congenital deformity of the feet, a congenital cystic kidney condition, and craniosynostosis. Dysmorphic features are described as cranial shape asymmetry with a high, prominent forehead consistent with her cranial suture abnormality. Neurodevelopmentally, she has moderate intellectual disability with persistent limitations in conceptual learning and adaptive functioning; caregivers report she requires substantial support for age-expected schoolwork and daily living skills, with difficulty following multistep instructions and needing close supervision for safety and routines. Her congenital anomalies have been present since birth, and she continues to have functional impact related to the foot deformity, including altered gait and reduced tolerance for prolonged walking. The overall presentation is consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome involving multiple congenital anomalies and dysmorphism. Prior genetic evaluation included a single-gene test performed on 2025-10-25, which was reported as negative.

Larry Hernandez is a 3-year-old male with a history notable for multiple congenital anomalies and severe intellectual disability. Congenital eye findings include other congenital malformations of the eyelid, contributing to persistent ocular asymmetry on exam. Cardiac history includes Ebstein’s anomaly, with ongoing cardiology follow-up for a structural tricuspid valve defect. Renal history is significant for congenital polycystic kidney disease, with known bilateral cystic changes and monitoring for kidney function over time. Neurodevelopmentally, he meets criteria for severe intellectual disability, with marked limitations in adaptive functioning and significant support needs for communication and daily activities. Overall presentation is consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance and the musculoskeletal system, and on exam he has dysmorphic facial features including downslanting palpebral fissures and a flat nasal bridge. Prior genetic testing is documented: chromosomal microarray performed on 2025-08-23 was negative.

Christine Garcia is a 15-year-old female with a history notable for multiple congenital anomalies and neurodevelopmental impairment. Cardiac history includes congenital pulmonary valve atresia, with early cyanosis and exertional limitation reported in childhood and ongoing need for cardiology surveillance. Craniofacial findings include microtia, described by family as a small, malformed external ear, contributing to cosmetic concerns and difficulty with ear-level devices. Gastrointestinal history is significant for congenital esophageal atresia, repaired in infancy, with persistent feeding-related symptoms including slow eating and intermittent dysphagia to solids. Neurodevelopmental course is consistent with severe intellectual disability, with substantial limitations in learning and adaptive functioning; she requires close supervision for daily activities and attends a structured special education program. Dysmorphic features are described as short palpebral fissures and a smooth philtrum, documented on prior examinations, in the context of a congenital malformation syndrome. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-12-04 that was negative.

Scott Rogers is a 3-year-old male with a history notable for multiple congenital anomalies including an atrial septal defect and esophageal atresia identified in infancy, with ongoing medical follow-up for these structural findings. He also carries a diagnosis of polycystic kidney disease, and caregivers report that renal disease has required periodic monitoring for kidney size and function. Neurodevelopmental history is significant for moderate intellectual disability with global delays affecting learning and adaptive skills; he requires close supervision for age-expected tasks and benefits from structured support for communication and daily routines. On exam, he has mild dysmorphic features with low-set ears and a flat nasal bridge, consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome. Family history is not contributory in the available record. Prior genetic testing is documented: chromosomal microarray performed on 2025-10-10 was negative.

Jennifer Evans is a 3-year-old female with history notable for multiple congenital anomalies including a congenital deformity of the feet with abnormal positioning present since birth, esophageal atresia requiring early surgical management with ongoing feeding and swallowing vulnerability, and a congenital brain malformation characterized by absence of the corpus callosum. Developmentally, she has had persistent speech and language delay with limited expressive vocabulary for age and reduced intelligibility, impacting communication in daily activities. Dysmorphic features are noted on exam with hypertelorism and low-set ears. Her overall presentation is consistent with a recognized congenital malformation syndrome involving multiple body systems, with the above structural findings and neurodevelopmental involvement documented since infancy. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-11-25, which was reported as negative.

Andrew Turner is a 15-year-old male with history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism and congenital hypotonia. Since infancy he has had low muscle tone with delayed acquisition of motor skills and ongoing easy fatigability; caregivers describe reduced endurance for age-appropriate activities with frequent need for rest and difficulty sustaining prolonged physical exertion. Clinical course has included episodic metabolic decompensation characterized by elevated serum lactate (typically 3.8–5.6 mmol/L, baseline ~2.1 mmol/L) and increased lactate-to-pyruvate ratio (about 28–35) during intercurrent illness, with partial improvement between episodes but persistent tendency toward mild lactic acid elevation. During symptomatic periods, he has had decreased activity tolerance and generalized weakness consistent with his hypotonia, without describing features outside the known mitochondrial metabolic disorder. Family history is significant for consanguinity; the parents are first cousins. Affected relatives include a maternal uncle with a documented mitochondrial metabolism disorder and lifelong low muscle tone, and a paternal cousin with congenital hypotonia requiring early physical therapy.

Elizabeth Stewart is a 7-year-old female with a history notable for esophageal atresia, managed in early life with ongoing feeding-related vulnerability. She also has a congenital brain malformation described as holoprosencephaly, with associated global functional impact including a specific developmental disorder of motor function; caregivers describe persistent difficulty with coordination and fine-motor tasks, affecting handwriting, dressing, and age-appropriate play skills. Congenital limb findings include other specified congenital deformities of the feet, contributing to an abnormal foot posture and gait mechanics that have required ongoing monitoring. Dysmorphic features are present, including midface hypoplasia and a short, upturned nasal bridge, consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome involving multiple systems. Family history is not documented in the available record. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-12-11, which was reported as negative.

Sandra Rogers is a 10-year-old female with a history notable for Ebstein’s anomaly and esophageal atresia, with congenital craniofacial asymmetry described as facial asymmetry and a broad, prominent forehead. She carries a diagnosis of severe intellectual disability with global functional impairment, requiring substantial support for communication, learning, and daily adaptive skills. Her congenital anomalies are described in the chart as multiple congenital malformations, and her developmental course has been consistent with significant cognitive limitations rather than a progressive neurologic decline. Dysmorphic features are limited in description to the facial asymmetry and prominent forehead; no additional specific craniofacial findings are documented in the available record. Past medical history includes the above congenital conditions without further elaboration in this encounter note. Prior genetic evaluation is documented: a single-gene test performed on 2025-09-25 was negative.

Jennifer Wright is a 6-year-old female with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency with lifelong intolerance to lactose-containing foods. Since infancy, exposure to breast milk/formula or later dairy products has reliably triggered profuse watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, bloating, and irritability, with improvement on strict lactose avoidance; even small amounts of hidden lactose (e.g., in processed foods) can provoke symptoms within hours. Metabolic evaluation has shown persistent carbohydrate malabsorption consistent with lactase deficiency, including repeated stool testing with acidic pH around 5.0 and positive reducing substances (1–2+), and breath hydrogen testing demonstrating a marked rise after lactose challenge (baseline 8 ppm to 62 ppm at 90 minutes). Neurologic history includes ataxia manifested by an unsteady, wide-based gait and poor coordination, with frequent tripping and difficulty with tandem walking and stairs, affecting playground activities; symptoms are described as chronic rather than episodic. Family history is notable for lactose intolerance in the father and a paternal aunt with longstanding dairy-triggered diarrhea; parents deny consanguinity.

Barbara Phillips is a 6-year-old female with history notable for a disorder of aromatic amino-acid metabolism with episodic biochemical decompensation and associated motor incoordination. During intercurrent illness and periods of reduced intake, caregivers report worsening unsteady gait and clumsiness with frequent stumbling and difficulty with tandem walking, consistent with ataxia that interferes with play and school activities. Between episodes, coordination improves but she remains more accident-prone than peers. Prior metabolic monitoring has shown elevated plasma phenylalanine, including a recent value of 980 µmol/L during a symptomatic period with partial improvement to 420 µmol/L on repeat testing when clinically stable, supporting a persistent tendency toward hyperphenylalaninemia with episodic worsening. Family history is significant for a paternal uncle described as having a similar amino-acid metabolism disorder requiring lifelong dietary management, and a maternal cousin with childhood-onset gait unsteadiness. The parents are first cousins, and the family reports multiple relatives from the same extended lineage with comparable metabolic concerns.

Laura Lee is a 12-year-old female with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency with lifelong lactose intolerance. Since infancy, dairy exposure has reliably triggered watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, bloating, and excessive gas, with symptoms beginning within hours of ingestion and improving with strict lactose avoidance; she tolerates lactose-free products. Metabolic evaluation has been consistent with carbohydrate malabsorption, including a hydrogen breath test showing an early rise in breath hydrogen to 45 ppm above baseline at 60 minutes after lactose load, and stool studies during symptomatic episodes demonstrating acidic stool (pH 5.0) with positive reducing substances. Neurologic history is notable for episodes of seizure-like activity without a specified seizure type; events have been intermittent, described as abrupt staring with unresponsiveness and generalized shaking lasting 1–2 minutes, followed by post-event fatigue, with no clear provocation identified. Family history is significant for a father with lactose intolerance beginning in childhood and a maternal uncle with recurrent seizures treated with antiseizure medication.

Alexander White is a 6-year-old male with history notable for a congenital malformation syndrome characterized by craniofacial dysmorphism and multiple congenital anomalies. He has a documented congenital malformation of the skull and facial bones, with a persistently abnormal head shape and facial asymmetry noted since infancy. Cardiac history includes Ebstein’s anomaly, followed since early life for structural tricuspid valve involvement. Developmentally, there is an established speech and language disorder; caregivers describe delayed expressive language acquisition with ongoing difficulty producing age-appropriate sentences and reduced intelligibility in longer utterances, impacting classroom communication. Physical examination has been notable for dysmorphic facial features, including facial asymmetry and an unusual cranial contour consistent with the known craniofacial malformation. A prior Gene panel performed on 2025-11-09 was reported as negative.

Jason Peterson is a 5-year-old male with a history notable for ostium secundum atrial septal defect and esophageal atresia, with ongoing multidisciplinary follow-up. He also has anotia, described on exam as absent external ear formation, contributing to a distinctly dysmorphic appearance with facial asymmetry. Developmentally, he carries a diagnosis of developmental disorder of speech and language, unspecified; caregivers report delayed expressive language with reduced intelligibility for age and functional impact on communication in preschool settings. His overall phenotype is consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance. There is no additional symptom-based diagnosis documented beyond these congenital and neurodevelopmental features. Prior genetic evaluation included chromosomal microarray performed on 2025-11-03, which was negative.

Sharon Cooper is a 7-year-old female with history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism and persistent problems with coordination. Since early childhood, caregivers describe a wide-based, unsteady gait with frequent tripping and difficulty with tandem walking, and she needs extra time for stairs and playground activities; symptoms are most apparent with fatigue and improve somewhat with rest. Neurologic exam has been characterized by gait ataxia with impaired balance on turning and inconsistent heel-to-shin performance, without describing a separate movement disorder diagnosis. Metabolic evaluation has supported a mitochondrial metabolism disorder with episodic elevations in serum lactate, including a documented lactate of 3.8 mmol/L (ref 0.5–2.2) during intercurrent illness and a repeat fasting lactate of 2.6 mmol/L on a well day, suggesting a persistent tendency toward mild hyperlactatemia with worsening during physiologic stress. Family history is significant for an affected maternal uncle with a similar lifelong unsteady gait and exercise intolerance; the parents deny consanguinity.

Alice Brown is a 4-year-old female with history notable for congenital esophageal atresia requiring early surgical management and ongoing feeding vulnerability, with intermittent choking and prolonged mealtimes compared with peers. She also has congenital positional skull asymmetry consistent with plagiocephaly, with persistent occipital flattening noted on exam. Renal history is significant for congenital polycystic kidney disease, followed clinically with periodic renal imaging; caregivers report episodes of abdominal fullness without acute pain, and no history provided of dialysis or transplant. Neurodevelopmentally, she carries a diagnosis of moderate intellectual disability with global delays affecting language acquisition and adaptive skills; she requires close supervision for age-appropriate self-care and benefits from structured routines. Physical appearance is described as dysmorphic in the setting of a congenital malformation syndrome, with downslanting palpebral fissures and low-set ears documented. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing on 2025-11-21, reported as negative.

Theresa Edwards is a 3-year-old female with history notable for a disorder of aromatic amino-acid metabolism consistent with tyrosinemia and episodic seizure-like events. Since infancy, metabolic monitoring has shown persistently elevated plasma tyrosine levels, typically 520–780 µmol/L (reference 35–110), with intermittent spikes during intercurrent illness; plasma phenylalanine has remained within age-appropriate range (e.g., 45–70 µmol/L). Liver-associated symptoms are not described in the available history, and current documentation focuses on biochemical elevation and dietary sensitivity reported by caregivers, with fatigue and irritability noted during periods of higher tyrosine values. She has also had recurrent paroxysmal events described as sudden stiffening with rhythmic shaking and post-event sleepiness, occurring roughly monthly, without a consistently documented trigger; events have led to emergency evaluation on more than one occasion. Family history is significant for consanguinity, with the parents reported to be first cousins. Affected relatives include an older paternal cousin with a similar tyrosine metabolism disorder requiring ongoing metabolic follow-up, and a maternal uncle with a history of recurrent seizures beginning in childhood.

Alexander Cook is a 14-year-old male with history notable for congenital malformation of the lacrimal apparatus, with longstanding tearing consistent with impaired tear drainage. Neurodevelopmental history includes agenesis of the corpus callosum, with associated global developmental disability affecting adaptive functioning and learning. Speech and language development has been delayed, described as an unspecified developmental disorder of speech and language with persistent difficulty producing age-appropriate expressive language and reduced intelligibility that impacts classroom participation and social communication. He carries a diagnosis consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance; on exam he has mild facial dysmorphism with a broad nasal bridge and low-set ears. Prior genetic evaluation included chromosomal microarray testing performed on 2025-12-10, which was negative.

Edward Young is a 5-year-old male with a history notable for congenital craniofacial asymmetry consistent with plagiocephaly and a small external ear, described since infancy. He also carries a diagnosis of esophageal atresia, identified early in life, with ongoing feeding-related vulnerability described by the family as needing careful pacing and texture modification to avoid choking or prolonged meals. Neurodevelopmental history is significant for severe intellectual disability with global functional limitations; he requires close supervision for safety, has markedly limited adaptive skills for age, and needs substantial support with communication and daily routines. Dysmorphic features on exam include plagiocephalic head shape and a small auricle. He has a documented diagnosis consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome, with multiple congenital anomalies present rather than an isolated finding. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-09-26, which was reported as negative.

Stephen Reed is a 7-year-old male with history notable for an atrial septal defect and a congenital malformation of the cerebral cortex, with associated developmental coordination disorder. Motor development has been impacted by persistent fine- and gross-motor incoordination, including clumsiness and difficulty with tasks requiring bilateral coordination and motor planning, affecting handwriting, dressing, and participation in age-appropriate sports. Neurodevelopmental history is also significant for a congenital malformation syndrome with dysmorphic features; on exam he has mild facial asymmetry and low-set ears. He carries a diagnosis consistent with a defined congenital malformation syndrome rather than an isolated anomaly, and his multisystem history has been followed in that context. There is no additional symptom complex described beyond what is captured by his known cardiac and brain malformations and coordination disorder. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-09-29, which was reported as negative.

Rebecca Moore is a 12-year-old female with history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism and persistent incoordination/ataxia affecting gait and fine motor control. Since early childhood, she has had an unsteady, wide-based gait with frequent tripping, difficulty with tandem walking, and clumsiness with tasks requiring rapid alternating movements; symptoms fluctuate with exertion and intercurrent illness and have interfered with sports participation and handwriting endurance at school. Metabolic monitoring has shown episodic lactic acid elevations consistent with mitochondrial dysfunction, including venous lactate 4.8 mmol/L during a viral illness and a repeat baseline lactate 2.6 mmol/L on a well day, with an elevated lactate-to-pyruvate ratio of 28; serum CK has been mildly increased at 320 U/L on one occasion. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with a similar lifelong unsteady gait and exercise intolerance, and a maternal grandmother reported to have episodic fatigue with prolonged exertion; there is no reported consanguinity.

Angela Coleman is a 12-year-old female with a history notable for a congenital craniofacial syndrome characterized by congenital narrowing of the lacrimal puncta with chronic tearing and intermittent ocular irritation, and a congenital malformation of the external ear with small, underdeveloped pinnae. Dysmorphic features on exam are consistent with her known syndrome, including microtia and visibly small lacrimal puncta. Neurodevelopmentally, she has severe intellectual disability with marked limitations in reasoning and adaptive functioning; she requires substantial assistance with communication and daily self-care and needs close supervision for safety in home and school settings. There is also a history of multiple congenital anomalies, with the above craniofacial findings representing key documented features. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-09-04, which was negative.

Gregory Taylor is a 15-year-old male with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency with lifelong lactose intolerance. Since infancy he has had reproducible gastrointestinal symptoms after exposure to lactose-containing foods, including crampy abdominal pain, bloating, and loose stools, with improvement when lactose is avoided; the family reports careful label reading and use of lactose-free alternatives. He also carries a diagnosis of other generalized epilepsy without status epilepticus, with recurrent generalized seizures described as sudden loss of awareness with bilateral stiffening and rhythmic jerking lasting 1–2 minutes, followed by postictal sleepiness and next-day fatigue that can interfere with school attendance. Metabolic monitoring has shown episodic elevation of blood lactate during intercurrent illness, most recently 3.8 mmol/L (reference 0.5–2.2) with normalization to 1.6 mmol/L when well, without persistent baseline elevation. Dysmorphic features noted on exam include a long narrow face and low-set ears. Family history is significant for generalized seizures in a maternal uncle; the parents are first cousins. Chromosomal microarray performed on 2025-10-25 was negative.

Timothy Collins is a 3-year-old male with history notable for decreased muscle tone since infancy, with persistent axial hypotonia and reduced spontaneous antigravity movements affecting gross motor progress and endurance during play. He has also had episodes of metabolic acidosis, including recurrent low serum bicarbonate with elevated anion gap during intercurrent illnesses, associated with tachypnea and fatigue; representative prior labs have shown bicarbonate 14–16 mmol/L with venous pH around 7.28–7.32, improving with supportive care but recurring episodically. Dysmorphic features described on exam include mild midface hypoplasia and low-set ears. Family history is significant for an older sibling with similar low tone in early childhood and a maternal uncle reported to have had recurrent “acidotic” hospitalizations as a child; the parents deny consanguinity. Prior genetic testing includes chromosomal microarray performed on 2025-08-25, reported as negative.

Kevin Collins is a 14-year-old male with a history notable for severe intellectual disability with significant limitations in adaptive functioning; he requires close supervision for daily activities and has longstanding global developmental impairment consistent with a multiple congenital anomalies picture. Congenital findings include a persistent interatrial communication consistent with an atrial septal defect, which has been followed clinically, and a congenital malformation of the eyelid with visible lid contour asymmetry affecting eyelid position. Dysmorphic features are present, including facial asymmetry and low-set ears. Overall presentation is consistent with a defined congenital malformation syndrome involving multiple systems. Family history is not documented in the available record. Prior genetic evaluation included a single-gene test performed on 2025-08-26, which was negative.

Maria Cox is a 4-year-old female with history notable for severe intellectual disability with significant limitations in adaptive functioning, requiring close supervision for daily activities and structured support for communication and learning. Neurodevelopmental history is further characterized by a congenital brain malformation consistent with agenesis of the corpus callosum. She also carries a diagnosis consistent with a defined congenital malformation syndrome, and on exam she has dysmorphic craniofacial features including a flattened midface and low-set ears. Head shape has been affected by congenital skull asymmetry, described as a positional cranial deformity with persistent asymmetry noted by caregivers since infancy. Renal history includes congenital polycystic kidney disease, with imaging previously demonstrating bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts; clinical course has required ongoing monitoring for renal function and growth. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-12-13, which was negative.

Laura Williams is an 8-year-old female with history notable for episodes of seizures without a specified type, described by caregivers as sudden spells of unresponsiveness with generalized stiffening and rhythmic shaking lasting 1–2 minutes, followed by several hours of sleepiness and confusion. Events have occurred intermittently since early childhood, sometimes clustering during intercurrent illness, and have led to missed school days and activity restrictions due to safety concerns. Her course is also marked by metabolic acidosis, with recurrent low serum bicarbonate on prior evaluations (typically 14–18 mmol/L) and compensatory low pCO₂ on venous blood gas, described as persistent across multiple draws rather than a single transient finding; caregivers note occasional rapid breathing and fatigue during these episodes. Dysmorphic features include a flat nasal bridge and mildly low-set ears on exam documentation. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with a childhood-onset seizure disorder and a paternal cousin reported to have recurrent “acid–base problems” requiring hospital visits; parents deny consanguinity. Prior genetic testing includes a gene panel performed on 2025-10-20 that was reported as negative.

Carol Clark is a 10-year-old female with history notable for persistent biochemical findings and longstanding coordination difficulties. Laboratory monitoring has repeatedly shown elevated plasma lactate in the 3.8–4.6 mmol/L range (ref 0.5–2.2) on several draws over the past year, with occasional higher values during intercurrent viral illnesses; basic metabolic panel has otherwise been stable at the times documented. Neurologically, she has chronic ataxia characterized by a wide-based, unsteady gait and impaired balance, with frequent tripping and difficulty with tandem walking; symptoms are present daily and interfere with running, stair negotiation, and participation in age-appropriate sports. On exam, she is described as having mild dysmorphic features including a broad nasal bridge and low-set ears. Family history is contributory for a maternal uncle with a lifelong unsteady gait and poor coordination, and the parents are first cousins. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-08-25, reported as negative.

Anthony Davis is a 15-year-old male with a history notable for congenital brain malformation described as holoprosencephaly and associated syndromic features consistent with a specified congenital malformation syndrome affecting multiple systems. He has moderate intellectual disability with global developmental delay; caregivers report longstanding limitations in adaptive functioning, requiring substantial support for academic learning and daily self-care tasks, with slower acquisition of communication and problem-solving skills compared with peers. Physical exam history is notable for dysmorphic features, including midface hypoplasia and closely spaced eyes, described as stable over time. Musculoskeletal history includes a congenital foot deformity consistent with other specified congenital deformities of the feet, present since birth and contributing to abnormal foot posture and gait mechanics. Family history information is not provided in the available record. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-08-23, which was reported as negative.

Kevin Carter is a 15-year-old male with a history notable for congenital brain malformation consistent with holoprosencephaly, along with congenital plagiocephaly/brachycephaly. Dysmorphic features include a flattened occiput with cranial asymmetry and midface hypoplasia. He also carries a diagnosis of a congenital atrial septal defect, described as a secundum-type defect, with ongoing cardiology follow-up noted in prior records. Neurodevelopmental history is significant for developmental delay/intellectual disability, with associated speech and language delay; caregivers report persistent difficulty with expressive language, reduced intelligibility, and need for support for age-appropriate communication and learning tasks. The overall phenotype has been described in prior documentation as consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting the face. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-08-21, which was reported as negative.

Charles Rogers is a 6-year-old male with a history notable for a congenital atrial septal defect and congenital absence of the external ear. Development has been characterized by a specific developmental disorder of motor function, with persistent delays in acquisition of age-appropriate gross and fine motor skills; caregivers describe clumsiness and difficulty with tasks requiring coordination, including challenges with handwriting and playground activities compared with peers. He has a documented congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance, and exam has been described as dysmorphic with low-set ears and facial asymmetry. The combination of congenital anomalies and motor developmental concerns has prompted prior genetic evaluation. A gene panel performed on 2025-09-25 was reported as negative.

Jacob Anderson is a 7-year-old male with history notable for metabolic acidosis and abnormal gait/coordination. Caregivers describe an unsteady, wide-based gait with frequent tripping and difficulty with tandem walking, more apparent with fatigue and limiting running and playground activities; on exam he demonstrates impaired coordination consistent with ataxia. Metabolic evaluation has shown persistent low serum bicarbonate with elevated anion gap on multiple occasions, with representative values including CO₂ 14–16 mmol/L and anion gap 18–22, consistent with ongoing metabolic acidosis; episodes have been associated with tachypnea and reduced stamina but without additional diagnostic labeling beyond the documented acid–base disturbance. Dysmorphic features are noted on physical examination, including mild midface hypoplasia and low-set ears. Family history is significant for consanguinity, with the parents reported to be first cousins, and relatives described as having similar coordination difficulties, including a maternal uncle with longstanding unsteady gait since childhood. Prior testing includes chromosomal microarray performed on 2025-12-29, reported as negative.

Patricia Hall is a 13-year-old female with history notable for multiple congenital anomalies and developmental delay. Congenital findings include a congenital deformity of the foot present since birth, with persistent structural malalignment affecting shoe fit and gait mechanics. She also has congenital polycystic kidney disease, described as bilateral renal cystic changes identified in childhood, followed clinically for renal involvement. Craniofacial morphology is notable for a small jaw consistent with mandibular hypoplasia, and she has mild dysmorphic features on exam characterized by micrognathia and a flattened midface profile. Neurodevelopmental history includes global developmental delay with a prominent speech and language disorder; caregivers report ongoing difficulty with expressive language and articulation that interferes with classroom participation and peer communication. Her overall presentation is consistent with a defined congenital malformation syndrome involving multiple systems, without extending beyond the specific features documented above. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-12-16, which was reported as negative.

Donna Jackson is an 8-year-old female with history notable for congenital craniofacial findings consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance. Dysmorphic features described by family include a persistently asymmetric palpebral fissure with a narrow-appearing eyelid opening, and mild facial asymmetry noted since infancy. She also has a congenital foot deformity described as an atypical positional shape present since birth, contributing to early difficulties with shoe fitting and balance during gross motor play. Developmentally, she carries a diagnosis of specific developmental disorder of motor function, with longstanding fine and gross motor coordination challenges; caregivers report she is slower with handwriting tasks, has difficulty with buttons and zippers, and is less coordinated than peers during running and jumping activities, requiring extra time for self-care routines.
