Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-12-19, which was reported as negative.

Edward Bailey is a 13-year-old male with history notable for a congenital brain malformation consistent with holoprosencephaly, accompanied by craniofacial dysmorphism. Facial features on exam include midface hypoplasia and a depressed nasal bridge. He also has plagiocephaly characterized by a flattened occiput with associated cranial asymmetry. Neurodevelopmentally, he carries a diagnosis of moderate intellectual disability with longstanding limitations in adaptive functioning, requiring substantial support for age-appropriate learning and daily living skills. His medical history is further significant for esophageal atresia without tracheoesophageal fistula, described as a congenital interruption of the esophagus with early feeding and swallowing difficulties consistent with this diagnosis. Overall presentation is consistent with a multiple congenital anomalies pattern, with structural brain involvement, craniofacial differences, and a congenital foregut malformation documented in the record. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-11-29, which was reported as negative.

Jonathan Sanchez is a 9-year-old male with history notable for tyrosinemia type 2 and congenital hypotonia. Parents describe low muscle tone noted since infancy with “floppy” posture and delayed acquisition of age-appropriate gross motor skills, with ongoing easy fatigability during prolonged walking and difficulty keeping up with peers in physical activities. Dysmorphic features are described on exam as mild hypertelorism and low-set ears. Metabolic history is consistent with persistent elevations of plasma tyrosine, with recent values reported around 620–780 µmol/L (ref 35–110) on repeated measurements, and intermittent detection of tyrosine metabolites on urine organic acid testing; symptoms are described as fluctuating with dietary protein intake. Family history is significant for similarly affected relatives, including an older maternal cousin with documented tyrosinemia type 2 and childhood hypotonia. The parents are first cousins. Prior testing includes a gene panel performed on 2025-08-17 that was reported as negative.

Ruth Hall is a 13-year-old female with a history notable for a congenital atrial septal defect and esophageal atresia, along with a recognized congenital malformation syndrome. Since early childhood she has had persistent motor coordination difficulties consistent with a specific developmental disorder of motor function, including clumsiness and poor fine-motor control that interfere with age-appropriate tasks such as handwriting and fasteners and contribute to slower performance in sports and playground activities. Dysmorphic features described on exam include low-set ears and a broad nasal bridge. Her congenital heart defect has been followed clinically, with a stable murmur reported historically, and her esophageal atresia has required ongoing attention to feeding and swallowing history, with intermittent dysphagia noted in past records. Family history is not documented in the available information. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2026-01-10, which was reported as negative.

Cynthia Stewart is a 3-year-old female with a history notable for congenital brain malformation consistent with holoprosencephaly, accompanied by severe intellectual disability with global functional limitations in communication and adaptive skills. Since infancy she has had syndromic features consistent with a congenital malformation syndrome, and on exam she is described as having mild dysmorphic facial characteristics including midface hypoplasia and closely spaced eyes. Orthopedic history includes a congenital foot deformity affecting the shape and positioning of the foot, present since birth and contributing to abnormal stance and gait mechanics during supported standing and walking. Developmentally, caregivers describe very limited acquisition of age-expected cognitive and self-care milestones, requiring extensive assistance with daily activities and close supervision for safety. Prior genetic testing is documented: chromosomal microarray (CMA) performed on 2025-12-27 was negative.

Linda Rogers is a 10-year-old female with history notable for congenital hypotonia, described since infancy as low axial tone with delayed acquisition of gross motor skills and ongoing easy fatigability with prolonged walking and difficulty with activities requiring core strength. Family history is significant for consanguinity, with the parents reported to be first cousins. A paternal cousin is described as having a similar metabolic condition with elevated tyrosine noted in childhood, and a maternal uncle reportedly had longstanding balance problems with an unsteady gait. No prior genetic test results were available for review in the record today.

He also carries a history of acidosis with metabolic features; available laboratory data are consistent with episodic low serum bicarbonate and low CO₂ on chemistry panels, for example bicarbonate 16–18 mmol/L with an anion gap around 18–20 during symptomatic periods, with partial improvement toward baseline (bicarbonate ~22 mmol/L) between episodes. During these episodes, caregivers describe fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance, without attributing a specific etiology beyond the documented acid-base disturbance. Family history is significant for seizures in a first-degree relative (mother with a history of generalized seizures beginning in adolescence) and a maternal uncle with recurrent seizure disorder; no parental consanguinity is reported. The combination of recurrent generalized seizures and intermittent metabolic acidosis has prompted ongoing specialty follow-up for characterization of seizure pattern and monitoring of acid-base status.

Kieran Griffith is a 5-year-old male with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency with dietary sensitivity since infancy, characterized by reproducible watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and excessive gas after lactose-containing feeds. Symptoms are persistent when lactose is ingested and improve with strict lactose avoidance; family reports careful label reading and use of lactose-free alternatives, with intermittent breakthrough episodes after accidental exposures. Prior metabolic evaluation has shown repeatedly low lactase activity on stool enzyme testing, and during symptomatic periods he has had mild non–anion gap metabolic acidosis (serum bicarbonate 18–20 mmol/L) and dehydration markers that resolve with rehydration and dietary restriction. Neurologic history includes episodic seizures without a specified type, described as sudden loss of awareness with generalized stiffening and rhythmic jerking lasting ~1–2 minutes, followed by postictal sleepiness; frequency is variable with months between events, and there is no consistent trigger reported. Family history is significant for similar lactose intolerance symptoms in the father and paternal grandmother, and a maternal uncle with recurrent seizures. Parents are first cousins.

Maren Montrose is a 13-year-old female with history notable for episodes of metabolic acidosis and impaired coordination. During symptomatic periods she develops fatigue and rapid breathing, and laboratory evaluation has shown low serum bicarbonate around 14–18 mmol/L with an increased anion gap (typically 18–24), consistent with recurrent acidosis rather than an isolated single finding. These episodes have been described as intermittent, with return toward baseline between events, and have at times limited participation in school and sports due to low stamina. Neurologically, she has had persistent incoordination with an unsteady gait and difficulty with rapid alternating movements; family reports frequent tripping and reduced accuracy with fine motor tasks such as handwriting, without describing a fixed weakness. Family history is significant for similar episodic “acidotic spells” in a maternal uncle and long-standing gait unsteadiness in an older sibling. The parents are first cousins, and the family reports no other known neurologic diagnoses in close relatives.

Leo Ainsley is a 12-year-old male with history notable for a disorder of aromatic amino-acid metabolism and neonatal hypotonia. Records describe decreased tone in the newborn period with “floppiness” and reduced spontaneous antigravity movement, requiring close feeding support early in life; tone has remained a prominent neurologic feature in his history with easy fatigability during prolonged physical activity. Metabolic monitoring has shown persistent elevation of plasma phenylalanine consistent with impaired aromatic amino-acid handling, with representative values including phenylalanine 980 µmol/L (ref 30–120) on one draw and 760 µmol/L on repeat testing several months later, while tyrosine has been comparatively low-normal at 42 µmol/L (ref 35–110). The biochemical pattern has been described as chronic rather than episodic, without clear illness-related spikes documented. Family history is notable for relatives with similar metabolic findings; a maternal cousin reportedly carries the same aromatic amino-acid metabolism disorder and required ongoing biochemical surveillance, and an older sibling has a history of low tone in infancy. No consanguinity is reported.

Dawson Ainsley is a 14-year-old male with a history notable for congenital malformations including a congenital right-sided foot deformity with atypical positioning/structure and a congenital pulmonary valve abnormality consistent with pulmonary valve stenosis. Beckett Tennyson is a 9-year-old male with a complex congenital history notable for polycystic kidney disease, agenesis of the corpus callosum, and an atrial septal defect. Spencer Valentine is a 15-year-old male with a history notable for congenital cardiac malformation characterized by pulmonary valve atresia, with longstanding cardiology follow-up and exercise tolerance limited compared with peers. Bridget Dalton is a 12-year-old female with a history notable for congenital heart disease, including an atrial septal defect and pulmonary valve atresia, as well as Ebstein anomaly. Anya Bramwell is a 4-year-old female with a history notable for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, with known bilateral renal cystic involvement documented in prior records. Hazel Seymour is a 6-year-old female with history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism and recurrent seizure-like episodes. Events are described as sudden spells of unresponsiveness with generalized stiffening and rhythmic shaking, lasting about 1–3 minutes, followed by post-event sleepiness and confusion for up to an hour; frequency has varied from monthly to several times per month, with occasional clustering during intercurrent illness and fatigue. Caregivers report that these episodes have disrupted school participation and require close supervision for safety. Metabolic evaluation has shown persistent lactic acid elevation consistent with impaired oxidative metabolism, with venous lactate typically 3.8–5.6 mmol/L (baseline on well days) and rising to 6.9 mmol/L during febrile episodes; serum pyruvate has also been elevated (0.18–0.24 mmol/L) with an increased lactate-to-pyruvate ratio. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with a childhood-onset seizure disorder and a maternal grandmother with a diagnosed mitochondrial metabolic condition characterized by chronically elevated lactate; no parental consanguinity is reported.

Malcolm Claremont is a 12-year-old male with a history notable for congenital polycystic kidney disease, previously identified esophageal atresia, and a neurodevelopmental profile characterized by developmental delay with ongoing speech and language impairment. Since early childhood, communication has remained behind peers, with persistent difficulty expressing age-appropriate language and being understood in conversation, contributing to functional limitations at school and in social settings. Gastrointestinal history includes the known esophageal atresia, with prior surgical/medical management implied by the diagnosis and continued relevance for feeding or swallowing history as documented in the chart. Sabrina Kendrick is a 12-year-old female with history notable for a mitochondrial metabolism disorder. Metabolic monitoring has shown persistent elevations in plasma lactate, with values documented around 3.6–4.2 mmol/L on repeat outpatient draws (reference <2.0), with episodic worsening during intercurrent illness; concurrent pyruvate has been mildly elevated (0.18–0.22 mmol/L), supporting an ongoing disturbance of mitochondrial energy metabolism.

Brady Hadley is a 6-year-old male with history notable for epilepsy characterized by generalized seizures that have occurred without clear focal onset; caregivers describe intermittent convulsive episodes with postictal sleepiness and transient confusion, impacting school attendance and requiring close supervision during activities such as bathing and swimming. Available laboratory data include persistently elevated serum lactate in the range of 3.8–4.6 mmol/L (reference 0.5–2.2) on repeat measurements, with episodic worsening during intercurrent illness, and mildly increased plasma alanine (e.g., 610 µmol/L, reference 200–500), prompting continued monitoring for a metabolic contribution to symptoms without assigning a specific metabolic diagnosis in the record. Family history is significant for seizures in a maternal uncle beginning in adolescence and a paternal first cousin with recurrent generalized convulsions; parents deny known consanguinity. No other prior test types, dates, or results were provided in the chart for review.

Aria Radcliffe is a 13-year-old female with history notable for persistent laboratory findings of other specified abnormalities, followed intermittently over time. Prior records describe recurrent elevations on metabolic screening, with serum lactate typically mildly to moderately high (e.g., 3.2–4.6 mmol/L on repeat draws) and occasional increased anion gap (e.g., 18–22) without a consistent acute illness trigger, suggesting a pattern that has been observed across more than one encounter rather than a single isolated result. Symptoms are present in day-to-day activities and are more noticeable with fatigue. Esme Ainsley is an 11-year-old female with history notable for congenital polycystic kidney disease and a congenital esophageal atresia identified in infancy, with ongoing medical complexity related to these birth conditions. Griffin Alder is an 11-year-old male with history notable for impaired coordination consistent with ataxia, described as a persistent unsteady gait with frequent stumbling and difficulty with balance-dependent tasks such as running, climbing stairs without holding a rail, and participating in sports; symptoms are observed across settings and have functional impact at school and during play. Laboratory evaluation has also shown other specified abnormal findings of blood chemistry, characterized by intermittently elevated plasma lactate ranging from 3.2–4.6 mmol/L (reference 0.5–2.2) and mild, recurrent elevation of alanine aminotransferase to 68–92 U/L (reference <45), with repeat measurements on separate occasions confirming persistence of these abnormalities rather than a single isolated result. Pierce Fenwick is a 9-year-old male with a history notable for multiple congenital anomalies and significant neurodevelopmental impairment. Roman Vaughn is a 10-year-old male with history notable for hyperphenylalaninemia and episodic seizures. Family history is significant for a sibling with elevated phenylalanine levels requiring dietary management, and a maternal cousin reported to have a childhood seizure history. Skye North is an 11-year-old female with history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism and congenital hypotonia. Family history is significant for similarly affected relatives, including a maternal uncle described as having lifelong low tone and exercise intolerance, and a sibling with early hypotonia. The parents are first cousins. Prior genetic testing includes a gene panel performed on 2025-09-16 that was reported as negative.

Dorian Pritchard is a 9-year-old male with a history notable for hyperphenylalaninemia and neonatal hypotonia. Hazel Nash is a 9-year-old female with a history notable for multiple congenital anomalies and motor developmental delay. Damian Somerset is a 7-year-old male with a history notable for agenesis of the corpus callosum and severe intellectual disability, with global functional limitations requiring close supervision for daily activities and substantial support for communication and learning. Piper Whitaker is a 10-year-old female with history notable for a disorder of aromatic amino-acid metabolism with persistent biochemical elevations consistent with hyperphenylalaninemia. Tobias Fairmont is an 11-year-old male with a history notable for a congenital ear malformation with small or underdeveloped external ears, and dysmorphic features including low-set ears with mild facial asymmetry on exam. Vivienne Iverson is a 13-year-old female with history notable for congenital cardiac anatomy consistent with pulmonary valve atresia, followed since infancy for cyanotic congenital heart disease physiology and associated exercise intolerance with early fatigue during vigorous activity. Tristan Fletcher is a 10-year-old male with history notable for recurrent seizures of unspecified type, described by family as intermittent episodes of sudden unresponsiveness with generalized stiffening and rhythmic shaking lasting 1–2 minutes, followed by several hours of fatigue and confusion; events have occurred a few times per year without a consistent trigger and have impacted school attendance. Rowan Grafton is a 12-year-old male with history notable for congenital heart disease described as pulmonary valve atresia, and a repaired esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula. Aurora Oakley is an 11-year-old female with history notable for congenital hypotonia, described since infancy with low axial tone and delayed acquisition of age-appropriate motor strength, contributing to easy fatigability with prolonged activity and a need for additional support for gross motor tasks. Kaia Jarrow is a 12-year-old female with history notable for esophageal atresia, with longstanding feeding and swallowing-related morbidity consistent with prior surgical repair and ongoing need for careful dietary textures and pacing to avoid choking or regurgitation. Dawson Voss is a 12-year-old male with history notable for lactose intolerance, with reproducible gastrointestinal symptoms after dairy ingestion; caregivers describe crampy abdominal discomfort and loose stools within a few hours of milk or ice cream, improving with lactose avoidance and use of lactase-treated products. Talia Merrick is a 7-year-old female with history notable for congenital ptosis affecting the eyelids and congenital facial asymmetry with a persistent uneven facial appearance. Owen Vaughn is a 3-year-old male with a history notable for a congenital brain malformation consistent with holoprosencephaly, along with a congenital pulmonary valve abnormality described as pulmonary valve atresia. Milo Kingsley is an 11-year-old male with history notable for congenital brain malformation described as holoprosencephaly, along with a congenital foot deformity consistent with an unspecified congenital talipes/clubfoot variant. Talia Radcliffe is a 4-year-old female with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency, with lactose exposure consistently provoking watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and irritability; symptoms improve with strict avoidance and recur with even small dietary challenges, contributing to feeding selectivity and difficulty maintaining regular daycare meals. Delilah Seymour is a 12-year-old female with a history notable for mild intellectual disability with ongoing need for academic supports and assistance with complex daily tasks. Maren Langford is a 6-year-old female with history notable for epilepsy with recurrent seizures that have persisted despite medication trials, with events described as abrupt staring and behavioral arrest at school and at home, sometimes progressing to generalized stiffening and rhythmic jerking with postictal sleepiness. Metabolic monitoring has shown recurrent elevations of plasma phenylalanine, with representative recent values in the 650–900 µmol/L range on multiple checks over the past year, with comparatively normal tyrosine around 55 µmol/L, consistent with a chronic tendency toward hyperphenylalaninemia rather than a single transient abnormal result. Family history is significant for a paternal uncle with a documented phenylalanine metabolism disorder requiring dietary management in childhood; no other affected relatives are reported. There is no prior genetic test information provided in the record for review today, and no dated prior test results were available at this visit.

Dorian Ingram is a 4-year-old female with a history notable for esophageal atresia, requiring ongoing attention to feeding tolerance and swallowing mechanics. She has developmental coordination disorder with persistent difficulty in age-expected fine and gross motor tasks; caregivers describe clumsiness and delayed acquisition of coordinated movements that interfere with play and self-care skills such as utensil use and dressing. Examination is notable for positional plagiocephaly with asymmetric cranial contour, and mild dysmorphic features including low-set ears and a short philtrum. Her medical complexity includes a congenital malformation syndrome involving multiple systems, reflected in the combination of congenital gastrointestinal anomaly, cranial shape differences, and neurodevelopmental motor impairment. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-12-09, which was reported as negative.

Zane Ulrich is a 14-year-old male with a history notable for congenital microcephaly and significant global neurodevelopmental impairment consistent with severe intellectual disability, with longstanding limitations in learning and adaptive functioning. He also carries a diagnosis of a congenital malformation syndrome with dysmorphic features; on exam he has small, underdeveloped external ears (microtia) and a relatively small head size consistent with his known microcephaly. Musculoskeletal history includes a congenital foot deformity described as an “other congenital deformity of feet,” present since birth and affecting foot shape and gait mechanics. Overall presentation is in keeping with multiple congenital anomalies without implying a single unifying cause. Prior genetic evaluation included chromosomal microarray (CMA) performed on 2025-10-31, which was reported as negative.

Zane Ulrich is an 8-year-old male with history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism and congenital hypotonia recognized in infancy. Caregivers describe persistently low muscle tone with poor antigravity strength since early childhood, with easy fatigability during age-appropriate play and slower acquisition of gross motor skills; he has required frequent rest breaks with prolonged walking and has difficulty keeping up with peers for running and climbing. On exam, tone is diffusely decreased with reduced resistance to passive movement and mild proximal weakness, without focal asymmetry. Metabolic monitoring has shown a recurrent pattern of lactic acid elevation, with plasma lactate typically ranging 3.2–4.8 mmol/L on multiple draws (reference <2.0), occasionally higher during intercurrent illness; serum bicarbonate has been mildly low at times (18–20 mmol/L), consistent with episodic metabolic stress rather than a single isolated result. Family history is significant for an older maternal uncle with a similar lifelong low-tone phenotype and exercise intolerance; there is no reported consanguinity between the parents.

Luca Lennox is a 9-year-old male with history notable for a mitochondrial metabolism disorder with episodic metabolic decompensation and a coexisting seizure disorder characterized by generalized seizures that have occurred in clusters at times. Parents describe intermittent periods of marked fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance, sometimes accompanied by poor appetite, during which he is less interactive and has difficulty keeping up with peers. During these episodes, laboratory evaluation has shown metabolic stress with elevated lactate (up to 4.8 mmol/L, baseline ~2.0 mmol/L) and an increased lactate-to-pyruvate ratio (28), with mild anion-gap metabolic acidosis (bicarbonate 17 mmol/L) that improves as he returns to baseline, suggesting a recurrent pattern rather than a single isolated event. Seizure history includes generalized convulsive events with postictal sleepiness; frequency has varied over time with occasional weeks without events followed by brief periods of increased activity. Family history is significant for parental consanguinity; the parents are first cousins. A paternal cousin reportedly has a mitochondrial metabolism disorder, and a maternal uncle has a history of generalized seizures.

Luca Lennox is an 8-year-old male with history notable for significant intellectual disability requiring substantial support for daily functioning and learning. Congenital findings include renal cystic disease consistent with medullary cystic involvement, with longstanding concern for structural kidney abnormalities rather than an acquired process. Craniofacial features are notable for plagiocephaly with facial asymmetry, and he has a congenital eyelid malformation affecting the lid margin/position. His overall pattern of multiple congenital anomalies aligns with a recognized congenital malformation syndrome, without extending beyond the specific anomalies documented above. A prior gene panel performed on 2025-11-24 was reported as negative.

Leona Tennyson is a 13-year-old female with history notable for a disorder of phenylalanine metabolism and epilepsy characterized by generalized seizures that are not intractable and without status epilepticus. Metabolic monitoring has shown persistently elevated plasma phenylalanine levels, with recent values around 720 µmol/L (reference 30–120 µmol/L) and episodic rises above 900 µmol/L during intercurrent illness; tyrosine has been relatively low at 38 µmol/L (reference 40–90 µmol/L), consistent with dietary sensitivity and the need for ongoing biochemical surveillance. Family history is significant for a paternal cousin with a similar phenylalanine metabolism disorder diagnosed in childhood, and a maternal aunt with a seizure disorder treated chronically with antiseizure medication; parents deny known consanguinity.

Leona Tennyson is a 13-year-old male with history notable for Ebstein’s anomaly of the tricuspid valve, with longstanding congenital heart disease followed since childhood. Owen Huxley is a 14-year-old female with history notable for congenital tricuspid valve atresia, requiring ongoing cardiac follow-up for cyanotic congenital heart disease physiology and exercise intolerance with easy fatigue compared with peers. Hudson Radcliffe is a 3-year-old female with history notable for a mitochondrial metabolism disorder and epilepsy characterized by other generalized seizures without status epilepticus. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with a seizure disorder beginning in childhood and a maternal grandmother reported to have a mitochondrial metabolism disorder with exercise intolerance; there is no known parental consanguinity.

Hudson Radcliffe is an 11-year-old male with a complex congenital history notable for esophageal atresia, agenesis of the corpus callosum, and congenital polycystic kidney disease. Skye Ulrich is an 8-year-old male with a history notable for congenital brain malformation described as agenesis of the corpus callosum, with associated global developmental delay and an ongoing developmental disorder of speech and language. Skye Ulrich is an 8-year-old male with history notable for a mitochondrial metabolism disorder and longstanding problems with coordination. Brooks North is a 10-year-old female with a history notable for multiple congenital anomalies and neurodevelopmental impairment. Naomi Fletcher is a 7-year-old female with history notable for epilepsy characterized by recurrent generalized seizures, described by caregivers as sudden episodes of loss of awareness with whole-body stiffening and rhythmic jerking lasting about 1–2 minutes, followed by postictal sleepiness and confusion for up to an hour. Theo Quarry is a 12-year-old female with a history notable for congenital pulmonary valve atresia and esophageal atresia, with longstanding multisystem congenital anomalies consistent with a specified congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance. Pierce Norwood is a 15-year-old female with history notable for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease and craniofacial findings consistent with a recognized congenital malformation syndrome. Bridget Whitaker is a 3-year-old male with history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism and neonatal hypotonia. Asher Prescott is a 7-year-old male with history notable for episodes of metabolic acidosis and impaired coordination. Asher Prescott is an 8-year-old male with a history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism and epilepsy characterized by generalized seizures that are not intractable and without a history of status epilepticus. Daphne Bexley is a 7-year-old male with history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism and persistent difficulty with coordination. Ophelia Dunley is a 12-year-old female with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency with dietary sensitivity since infancy. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with lifelong lactose intolerance attributed to congenital lactase deficiency, and a paternal cousin with chronic gait unsteadiness described as ataxia beginning in childhood. Parents deny consanguinity.

Ophelia Dunley is an 11-year-old female with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency with lifelong intolerance to lactose-containing foods. Jude Emerson is a 3-year-old female with history notable for a secundum atrial septal defect and a congenital foot deformity. Dysmorphic features have been described on exam, including a broad nasal bridge and low-set ears, in the context of a congenital malformation syndrome predominantly affecting facial appearance. Cardiac history centers on the atrial septal defect without additional structural detail available in the record; there is no characterization here of symptoms, shunt size, or prior interventions. Orthopedic history includes the congenital foot anomaly, with no laterality or specific type documented. Prior genetic evaluation included single-gene testing performed on 2025-12-21, which was negative.

Rowan Harlan is a 3-year-old female with history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism and recurrent seizure-like episodes. Caregivers describe intermittent events of sudden stiffening with rhythmic shaking and unresponsiveness lasting about 1–3 minutes, followed by sleepiness for up to an hour; events have occurred both with intercurrent illness and without clear triggers, and have disrupted daycare participation due to post-event fatigue. Metabolic monitoring has demonstrated persistent lactic acid elevation consistent with mitochondrial metabolic dysfunction, with serum lactate typically 3.8–5.2 mmol/L on repeat checks and occasional higher values during febrile episodes; a concurrent mild metabolic acidosis has been documented during symptomatic periods (bicarbonate 17–19 mmol/L). Between episodes, energy is variable with easy fatigability reported during active play, though baseline alertness is generally preserved. Family history is significant for a maternal aunt with a childhood-onset seizure disorder and a maternal cousin reported to have a mitochondrial metabolic condition; parents deny known consanguinity.

Rowan Harlan is a 3-year-old female with history notable for multiple congenital anomalies and developmental delay. Craniofacial findings include a congenital abnormality of the external ear with visible auricular malformation, and a positional skull shape difference consistent with plagiocephaly noted since infancy. Cardiac history includes a documented atrial septal defect described as a secundum-type defect, followed clinically. Neurodevelopmentally, she has a specific developmental disorder of motor function with persistent delays in gross and fine motor skills impacting age-expected coordination and motor planning; caregivers report ongoing difficulty with tasks requiring balance and hand dexterity. Her overall presentation is consistent with a recognized congenital malformation syndrome affecting multiple systems. On exam, dysmorphic features are described as asymmetric cranial contour and a visibly malformed pinna. Prior genetic evaluation included a gene panel performed on 2025-12-09, which was reported as negative.

Griffin Seymour is a 7-year-old male with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency with lifelong intolerance to lactose-containing feeds. Caregivers describe reproducible gastrointestinal symptoms after dairy exposure, including watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and increased gassiness within hours of ingestion; symptoms improve with strict lactose avoidance and recur with accidental exposures, leading to intermittent dehydration risk during more severe episodes. He also carries a diagnosis of other generalized epilepsy, not intractable, without status epilepticus. Seizure history is described as generalized events with impaired awareness and bilateral shaking, lasting a few minutes with postictal sleepiness and next-day fatigue; episodes have occurred intermittently rather than daily, without any history of prolonged convulsive episodes requiring emergent treatment for status epilepticus. From a metabolic standpoint, clinical records include persistently low lactase activity consistent with congenital lactase deficiency, and stool testing during symptomatic periods has shown acidic stool (pH ~5.0) with positive reducing substances, supporting carbohydrate malabsorption during exposures. Family history is significant for a father with generalized seizures beginning in adolescence and a paternal aunt with lifelong lactose intolerance consistent with congenital lactase deficiency; no consanguinity is reported.

Griffin Seymour is a 3-year-old female with history notable for a disorder of mitochondrial metabolism accompanied by persistent gait and trunk incoordination. Parents describe delayed acquisition of coordinated ambulation with a wide-based, unsteady gait and frequent falls, worse with fatigue and intercurrent illness; she often needs hand support on uneven surfaces and has difficulty with stairs and running compared with peers. Neurologic exam is described as consistent with ataxia, with truncal sway and dysmetria noted during reaching tasks. Metabolic evaluation has shown recurrent biochemical evidence of mitochondrial dysfunction, including episodic elevations of serum lactate (typically 3.8–5.2 mmol/L during illnesses, baseline ~2.6 mmol/L) with an increased lactate-to-pyruvate ratio (around 25–30) and intermittently elevated plasma alanine (up to 620 µmol/L), reported as persisting across multiple draws rather than a single isolated result. Family history is significant for an older brother with a similar unsteady gait beginning in toddlerhood and a maternal aunt with a diagnosed mitochondrial metabolism disorder; there is no reported parental consanguinity.

Jude Iverson is an 8-year-old male with a history notable for epilepsy characterized by generalized seizures that have been described as intractable, with events occurring in clusters several times per month and causing postictal sleepiness and missed school days. Caregivers report intermittent breakthrough episodes despite ongoing management, with no specific provoking factors consistently identified. His medical record also documents metabolic acidosis, described as persistent on repeat chemistry testing, with serum bicarbonate typically in the 15–18 mmol/L range and a corresponding low CO₂ on basic metabolic panels; venous blood gas has shown acidemia with pH around 7.28–7.32 during evaluations. Family history is significant for seizures in a maternal uncle (generalized convulsions beginning in adolescence) and a paternal cousin with a chronic problem described as “low bicarbonate” requiring periodic medical follow-up. Tristan Voss is a 4-year-old male with history notable for recurrent seizure-like episodes without a specified seizure type. Family history is significant for a maternal uncle with childhood-onset seizures treated into adolescence, and a paternal first cousin with recurrent febrile seizures in early childhood; parents deny consanguinity.

Freya Yorke is a 4-year-old female with history notable for congenital lactase deficiency with symptoms beginning in infancy. Caregivers describe reproducible gastrointestinal intolerance to lactose-containing feeds, with watery diarrhea and abdominal discomfort shortly after exposure; symptoms improve with strict lactose avoidance and recur with accidental ingestion, consistent with a persistent dietary sensitivity rather than episodic illness. Family history is significant for similar lactose intolerance in the father since infancy and a paternal aunt with longstanding gait unsteadiness consistent with ataxia. Parents report consanguinity, stating they are first cousins.

Bennett Dawes is a 12-year-old male with history notable for a disorder of phenylalanine metabolism and epilepsy characterized by generalized seizures that can progress to prolonged events. Metabolic monitoring has shown persistently elevated plasma phenylalanine levels, with recent values around 980 µmol/L (reference 30–120 µmol/L), and intermittent elevations despite dietary sensitivity; tyrosine has been low-normal at times (e.g., 35 µmol/L, reference 40–90 µmol/L). Neurologically, caregivers describe recurrent generalized convulsive seizures with postictal confusion and fatigue, and there is concern for episodes lasting several minutes with occasional clustering, impacting school attendance and requiring close supervision during activities. Family history is significant for similarly affected relatives, including a paternal uncle with a phenylalanine metabolism disorder requiring dietary management and a maternal cousin with generalized epilepsy. The parents are first cousins, and the family reports multiple relatives with seizure disorders across both sides of the family.

Bennett Dawes is a 13-year-old female with history notable for a neonatal hypotonia phenotype, described as “floppy” in infancy with low axial tone and delayed acquisition of head control, requiring ongoing supportive therapies through early childhood for generalized weakness and poor endurance. Current functioning is limited by easy fatigability with prolonged activity, with persistent low muscle tone on exam by report. Her metabolic history includes episodes of metabolic acidosis with documented low serum bicarbonate and elevated anion gap during intercurrent illnesses; prior labs have shown bicarbonate as low as 14–16 mmol/L with venous pH around 7.28–7.32, improving with treatment but recurring over time, consistent with episodic rather than single isolated findings. During stable periods, bicarbonate has been closer to the low-normal range (18–21 mmol/L). Family history is significant for similarly affected relatives, including a younger brother with neonatal hypotonia and recurrent acidosis episodes requiring emergency evaluation. The parents are first cousins, and there is also a maternal cousin reported to have recurrent “acidotic crises” in childhood.
